Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Phoenix AZ
529 AM MST Thu Feb 9 2023

.UPDATE...
Updated Fire Weather discussion.

&&

.SYNOPSIS...
With dry weather persisting, temperatures will warm to above normal 
levels through the end of the week with locally breezy to windy 
conditions. A low pressure system will track through the region 
Sunday and Monday resulting in a cooling trend. Moisture with this
system will be extremely limited with precipitation chances 
mainly being confined to the higher terrain areas of Arizona. 

&&

.DISCUSSION...
Latest water vapor imagery and streamline analysis reveal a 
divergent, but dry northerly flow across the Desert Southwest, 
situated between a vort max across the southern Rockies and a 
ridge in the eastern Pacific. The high amplitude ridge will 
migrate eastward today across the intermountain West. Reflection 
at the surface will be in the form of an anomalously strong 
surface high building in behind a cold front that will move 
through this morning. Consequently, the low-level pressure 
gradient will be rather tight, resulting in windy conditions, 
particularly across the foothills and higher terrain east of 
Phoenix this morning, where the HREF suggests a 50-80 percent 
chance localized gusts could reach 40 mph. Widespread breeziness 
is expected to develop later in the morning across the lower 
deserts with the potential for gusts up to 30 mph. In addition to 
the breezy/windy conditions, much drier air will mix to the 
surface and the NBM indicates dewpoints could reach the single 
digits by this afternoon.

Cold air pooling across the higher terrain will reinvigorate the 
surface high tonight, which will translate into another period of 
windy conditions across the higher terrain and a general 
breeziness across the lower deserts. With the ridge sliding 
further eastward, the flow will also become more easterly and the 
strongest winds will shift further south into southern Arizona. 
However, the latest ECMWF ensemble indicates gusts will likely 
still reach 25-30 mph as far north as Phoenix during the late 
morning and afternoon. The flow will also be strong enough to 
promote areas of blowing dust, particularly across northern Pinal 
and southern Maricopa Counties. Meanwhile, a return to above 
normal temperatures is anticipated with highs in the lower 70s.

A continued warming trend is likely Saturday as a southwesterly 
flow develops between a ridge to our east and a deepening low 
pressure system across the California Coast. This will help to 
boost temperatures a few more degrees into the mid 70s, though 
abundant high clouds will somewhat temper the effects of the sun.

The California low pressure system is generally expected to move 
southeastward towards Rocky Point Sunday, though there is still 
considerable uncertainty with regard to the exact position and 
speed of the low. A slower approach would translate into a 
slightly warmer day Sunday with highs again reaching the lower 70s
across the Phoenix area, while conditions would be considerably 
cooler if the low moves faster and further east. Limited moisture 
transport will relegate the highest rain chances to the higher 
terrain east of Phoenix Sunday night and Monday, however PoPs 
only peak at 40 percent. One model cluster depicting a stronger 
low generates slightly more QPF, though only a few tenths of an 
inch are expected with this scenario across the higher terrain. 
Across the lower deserts including Phoenix, a few hundredths of an
inch are possible.

&&

.PREVIOUS DISCUSSION...
As the upper vorticity center swings across northern Sonora Monday, 
mean troughing will become established across the intermountain west 
and central Conus during the midweek period. Ensemble spread grows 
rather substantially with potential outcomes ranging from an 
anomalous cold core digging into northern AZ to shortwave energy 
being pulled well downstream into the central Conus before 
intensifying. Ensemble distribution appears rather equal yielding 
low forecast confidence towards the end of this forecast period. 

&&

.AVIATION...Updated at 1216Z. 

South-Central AZ including KPHX, KIWA, KSDL, KDVT, KGYR, KGEU: 

Winds in the lower troposphere and at the surface will strengthen
this morning leading to northeasterly breeziness (gusts 20-25kts)
at the surface after the morning inversion dissipates between 
17Z-18Z. Tonight, winds in the lower levels above the surface 
strengthen while the surface winds weaken. After about 06Z, some 
TAF sites including KPHX are anticipated to have LLWS conditions 
due to light and variable surface winds contrasted with 
northeasterly winds to 30kts at 2kft AGL. Other TAF sites are 
anticipated to have less of a contrast due to more distinct 
northeasterly surface winds and/or less strong winds in the lower 
levels above the surface. As for sky cover, only minor passing 
cirrus at most. 

Southeast California/Southwest Arizona including KIPL and KBLH: 

Winds in the lower troposphere and at the surface will strengthen
this morning leading to northerly breeziness (gusts 20-25kts) at 
the surface after the morning inversion dissipates between 
17Z-18Z. At KBLH, between about 15Z-18Z, anticipate sufficient
contrast between light surface winds and stronger winds in the
lower levels above the surface to cause LLWS conditions. That will
dissipate when surface winds strengthen. As for sky cover, only
minor passing cirrus at most. 

&&
 
.FIRE WEATHER... 
Strong high pressure will build across the Desert Southwest
through Friday, resulting in a relatively tight pressure gradient
along with periods of breezy to windy conditions. Low RHs 
generally below 15 percent will also be prevalent. Some spots may 
reach critical RH and wind thresholds today across portions of 
southern Gila County. The threat will shift a bit further south 
Friday, affecting portions of Pinal, southern Maricopa and Yuma 
Counties. However, overall fire danger remains low, given the
relatively moist fuels.

Lingering breeziness is anticipated Saturday, though relative 
humidities will climb steadily through the weekend ahead of a low 
pressure system. A few showers will be possible mainly Sunday 
night and Monday as the system moves through the Desert Southwest,
however, the highest rain amounts will be relegated to the higher
terrain east of Phoenix and will generally amount to less than a 
tenth of an inch. Another period of windy conditions will be 
possible Tuesday/Wednesday as a stronger low pressure system moves
through northern Arizona.
